raw_text:
Media seek Jackson 'juror' notes
 
 Reporters covering singer Michael Jackson's trial in California have asked to see questionnaires completed by potential jurors.
 
 Lawyers for news organisations said it was "really vital" for the responses of 250 potential jurors to be made public "to serve as a check on the process". Santa Barbara County Superior Court is due to consider the request on Monday. Mr Jackson denies child molestation. It is estimated his trial will cost Santa Barbara county up to $4m (£2.13m).
 
 Meanwhile Michael Jackson's mother has said she is "100% certain" her son did not commit the child abuse charges he faces. The court is currently selecting 12 jurors and eight stand-by jurors for the trial, a process delayed until at least Thursday after a member of the star's legal team was hit by family illness. Defence lawyers argued against the bid by Associated Press and other news organisations to have potential jurors' responses made public.
 
 "The release of the completed jury questionnaires does not serve any purpose other than to add to the sensationalist coverage of this case," a motion by Mr Jackson's lawyers stated. The estimated total costs of the trial, expected to last five months, range from $2.5m (£1.33m) to $4m (£2.13m) of local taxpayers' money. Those estimates do not include costs to the city of Santa Maria, the Superior Court or for the investigation and prosecution of the case. The cost of security and other needs around the courthouse has been estimated at $40,000 (£21,000) per day, said Jason Stilwell, a special projects manager at the county administrator's office.
 
 Mr Jackson, 46, denies plying a boy with alcohol and molesting him. His mother Katherine Jackson told US TV network Fox News on Sunday that her pop star son told her he was innocent. "I believe that for one reason - I know his character," she said. "He loves children. You don't molest anything that you love." Describing Mr Jackson as "a good person", the mother-of-nine said she feared he would not be given a fair trial. "I can't sleep thinking about what these wicked people might try to do to him," she said.
llama3.2:1b: Media has requested and been granted access to potential jurors' questionnaires completed by 250 potential jurors for Michael Jackson's trial in California, citing the need for transparency as a check on the process. The request is due to be considered by Santa Barbara County Superior Court on Monday and could lead to the release of jury questionnaires once they are made public.
llama3.2:3b: Reporters covering Michael Jackson's trial have asked for completed questionnaires from 250 potential jurors, which lawyers oppose due to concerns of sensationalist coverage. The estimated total costs of the trial are between $2.5m and $4m, with additional security costs. Michael Jackson denies child molestation charges and claims his mother is "100% certain" he did not commit them.
gemma2:2b: Reporters are seeking public access to completed questionnaires of potential jurors in Michael Jackson's trial.  Jackson's lawyers oppose this request, stating it adds to sensationalism. The estimated trial cost is between $2.5 and $4 million.  Michael Jackson denies child molestation charges. His mother believes he is innocent and expresses concern about a fair trial.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Media are seeking to see completed questionnaire responses from 250 potential jurors in Michael Jackson's trial in California, while prosecutors argue the documents should not be made public as they could serve as a check on the process and add to the trial's cost.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Michael Jackson's media coverage seeks his jury responses, lawyers objecting that it will only sensationalize the case and costs have been estimated at over $4 million. The trial is expected to cost up to $4 million and involve 12 jurors and stand-by jurors. Jackson's mother believes he is innocent and fears a fair trial won't be given.
qwen2.5:3b: Media seek public access to potential jurors' questionnaire responses in Michael Jackson's child molestation trial, which is estimated to cost up to $4 million. News organizations argue this would serve as a check on the process and add transparency. However, Jackson’s lawyers oppose making the responses public, citing their sensationalist nature. The jury selection process has been delayed due to illness affecting one of the defense team members. Estimates for the trial range from $2.5 million to $4 million, with additional costs including security and other courthouse needs estimated at $40,000 per day. Jackson’s mother, Katherine Jackson, asserts her son is innocent and believes he will receive a fair trial despite concerns over potential prejudice.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and preserves key ideas, details, and information from the original text. It provides an overview of the main points without adding or subtracting any information. The summary does not include explanations, justifications, or reasoning processes.

But these numbers don't include costs to Santa Maria or the investigation.

</think>

The reporter in charge of covering Michael Jackson's trial in California is requesting that potential jurors fill out questionnaire forms before the trial. Lawyers for news organizations emphasize that these responses are crucial for checking the process and are vital for their findings. The request will be considered by Monday, with estimated costs ranging from $2.5m to $4m local taxes. However, these costs do not include expenses to Santa Maria, the Superior Court, or for investigation and prosecution of the case. Security and other daily needs at the courthouse were projected to cost $40k each day. Michael Jackson's mother said she was 100% certain his kids didn't commit the charges he faces. The trial is selecting 12 jurors with 8 stand-by, but the process will be delayed until Thursday due to a member of his legal team facing health issues. Defense lawyers argue against this motion, stating sensationalist coverage.
tinyllama:1.1b: The media is seeking responses from a total of 250 potential jurors in Michael Jackson's upcoming child molestation trial in Santa Barbara County, California. The motion argues that the responses are important and necessary for checks on the process, as no official court documents or press reports have made available such information. The court is considering Monday whether to allow the requests from Associated Press and other news organizations to be submitted. The estimated total costs of the trial range from $2.5m (£1.33m) to $4m (£2.13m) of local taxpayers' money, with estimates suggesting an additional $80,000 per day for security and other needs around the courthouse. The cost of security and other needs is estimated at $40,000 per day, according to special projects manager Jason Stilwell at the Santa Barbara County Administrative Office. The motion argues that publishing the completed juror questionnaires would add nothing but distraction to an already highly-publicized case. Katheriine Jackson tells US TV network Fox News that she is "100% certain" her son does not molest boys and denies claims he played a boy with alcohol and molested him. The motion further argues that allowing the requests would be unfair to Michael Jackson, who has already endured the media's harsh scrutiny since news of his death emerged in June 2009.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Michael Jackson's upcoming trial has raised concerns over whether potential jurors will have anonymity in the process. The Santa Clara County Superior Court, which is handling the case, is currently considering requests for some jurors to provide their responses to questionnaires, but it is unclear what consequences they may face if they don't comply.

The trial is expected to last five months and costs have been estimated at $4m (£2.13m) per month. The cost of security and other needs around the courthouse has also been estimated at $40,000 (£21,000) per day. Local taxpayers are expected to cover these expenses, which include costs to the city of Santa Maria, the Superior Court, and for the investigation and prosecution of the case. 

Despite concerns about potential juror anonymity, some reporters have sought to obtain copies of the questionnaires to examine them closely. It is unclear whether these efforts will serve any purpose other than to add to the sensationalist coverage of this case. Defence lawyers argue against the requests, arguing that publicizing the responses would be a "sensationalist" aspect of the trial and might harm the reputation of Michael Jackson.

Despite the uncertainty surrounding anonymity for potential jurors, reporters have continued to cover the trial closely, highlighting the importance of the case and its implications for celebrities and public figures.
